Ancient_Greek_philosophy.name: Ancient Philosophy
Ancient_Greek_philosophy.description: Philosophy in the ancient Greek and Roman world, beginning with the Pre-Socratics and continuing through Neoplatonism.

subEras.name: Pre-Socratic Philosophers
subEras.description: Early Greek philosophers who sought natural explanations for the cosmos, predating Socrates.

thinkers.name: Thales of Miletus
thinkers.note: Considered the first Western philosopher; proposed water as the fundamental principle.

thinkers.name: Anaximander
thinkers.note: Introduced the 'apeiron' (the boundless) as the source of all things.

thinkers.name: Anaximenes
thinkers.note: Believed air to be the primary substance through processes of rarefaction and condensation.

thinkers.name: Heraclitus
thinkers.note: Emphasized constant change (flux) and the unity of opposites.

thinkers.name: Parmenides
thinkers.note: Argued that true being is unchanging, making change an illusion.

thinkers.name: Zeno of Elea
thinkers.note: Famous for paradoxes challenging motion and plurality.

thinkers.name: Empedocles
thinkers.note: Proposed four 'roots' (earth, water, air, fire) plus Love and Strife as cosmic forces.

thinkers.name: Anaxagoras
thinkers.note: Posited that 'Mind' (Nous) sets the universe in motion; everything contains a portion of everything else.

thinkers.name: Democritus
thinkers.note: Developed atomism, explaining the world via indivisible atoms in the void.

subEras.name: Sophists
subEras.description: Traveling teachers of rhetoric and virtue, often emphasizing relativism and skepticism.

thinkers.name: Protagoras
thinkers.note: Famous for 'Man is the measure of all things,' endorsing a form of relativism.

thinkers.name: Gorgias
thinkers.note: Explored paradoxes of being and language, claiming 'Nothing exists.'

thinkers.name: Thrasymachus
thinkers.note: Noted in Plato's Republic for asserting 'Justice is the advantage of the stronger.'

subEras.name: Classical Philosophy (Socrates, Plato, Aristotle)
subEras.description: Centered in Athens, focusing on ethics, political theory, and systematic inquiry.

thinkers.name: Socrates
thinkers.note: Pioneered the Socratic method of questioning; emphasized self-knowledge and ethics.

thinkers.name: Plato
thinkers.note: Founder of the Academy; advanced Theory of Forms and wrote influential dialogues.

thinkers.name: Aristotle
thinkers.note: Student of Plato, tutor to Alexander the Great; systematized logic, metaphysics, ethics.

subEras.name: Hellenistic Philosophy
subEras.description: Post-Alexander the Great’s conquests; focus on ethics and achieving tranquility.

keyThinkers.name: Zeno of Citium
keyThinkers.note: Founder of Stoicism; taught virtue as the only good and living in harmony with nature.

keyThinkers.name: Seneca
keyThinkers.note: Roman Stoic philosopher, statesman, and dramatist.

keyThinkers.name: Epictetus
keyThinkers.note: Emphasized inner freedom and self-control; wrote the Enchiridion.

keyThinkers.name: Marcus Aurelius
keyThinkers.note: Roman Emperor; author of the Meditations, focusing on Stoic ethics.

keyThinkers.name: Epicurus
keyThinkers.note: Advocated moderate pleasure, ataraxia (tranquility), and materialist atomism.

keyThinkers.name: Lucretius
keyThinkers.note: Roman poet-philosopher who expounded Epicureanism in De Rerum Natura.

keyThinkers.name: Pyrrho of Elis
keyThinkers.note: Founded Pyrrhonian Skepticism, advocating suspension of judgment (epoché).

keyThinkers.name: Carneades
keyThinkers.note: Head of the Platonic Academy; advanced Academic Skepticism, focusing on probability.

keyThinkers.name: Diogenes of Sinope
keyThinkers.note: Embodied Cynic ideals of radical asceticism and living 'according to nature.'

subEras.name: Neoplatonism
subEras.description: Philosophical system inspired by Plato, focusing on the One and emanation, influencing early Christian thought.

thinkers.name: Plotinus
thinkers.note: Founder of Neoplatonism; introduced concepts of the One, Nous, and the Soul’s descent.

thinkers.name: Porphyry
thinkers.note: Student of Plotinus; wrote Isagoge (introduction to Aristotle’s categories).

thinkers.name: Proclus
thinkers.note: Developed a complex Neoplatonic system of triadic emanations.

MedievalPhilosophy.name: Medieval Philosophy
MedievalPhilosophy.description: Era focused on the synthesis of classical philosophy (especially Aristotle and Plato) with Christian, Jewish, and Islamic theology.

thinkers.name: Augustine of Hippo
thinkers.note: Combined Christian doctrine with Platonism, significant for his works on sin, free will, and time.

thinkers.name: Boethius
thinkers.note: Authored The Consolation of Philosophy, reconciling divine foreknowledge and human freedom.

thinkers.name: John Scotus Eriugena
thinkers.note: Synthesized Christian thought with Neoplatonism; introduced concept of theophany.

thinkers.name: St. Anselm of Canterbury
thinkers.note: Developed the ontological argument ('that than which nothing greater can be conceived').

thinkers.name: Peter Abelard
thinkers.note: Applied logical analysis in Sic et Non, highlighting theological contradictions.

thinkers.name: Thomas Aquinas
thinkers.note: Synthesized Aristotelian philosophy with Christian theology in the Summa Theologica.

thinkers.name: John Duns Scotus
thinkers.note: Emphasized 'haecceity' (thisness) and a strong voluntarist perspective.

thinkers.name: William of Ockham
thinkers.note: Nominalist best known for Ockham’s Razor: 'do not multiply entities beyond necessity.'

RenaissancePhilosophy.name: Renaissance Philosophy
RenaissancePhilosophy.description: Marked by humanism, revived interest in classical texts, and early shifts toward modern scientific inquiry.

thinkers.name: Niccolò Machiavelli
thinkers.note: Wrote The Prince, focusing on political power, realism, and secular statecraft.

thinkers.name: Desiderius Erasmus
thinkers.note: Christian humanist who criticized Church corruption and advocated for religious tolerance.

thinkers.name: Giovanni Pico della Mirandola
thinkers.note: Author of Oration on the Dignity of Man; combined Platonic, Aristotelian, and esoteric traditions.

EarlyModernPhilosophy.name: Early Modern Philosophy
EarlyModernPhilosophy.description: Characterized by the Scientific Revolution, rationalism vs. empiricism debates, and new foundations for knowledge.

thinkers.name: René Descartes
thinkers.note: Introduced methodological skepticism; 'I think, therefore I am.' Mind-body dualist.

thinkers.name: Baruch Spinoza
thinkers.note: Advocated monism (God or Nature); wrote Ethics in a geometric style.

thinkers.name: Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz
thinkers.note: Proposed monads, principle of sufficient reason, and 'best of all possible worlds.'

thinkers.name: Thomas Hobbes
thinkers.note: Materialist; Leviathan outlines a social contract justifying absolute rule.

thinkers.name: John Locke
thinkers.note: Mind as tabula rasa; influential on liberal political theory (natural rights).

thinkers.name: George Berkeley
thinkers.note: 'Esse est percipi'—immaterialist holding that existence depends on perception.

thinkers.name: David Hume
thinkers.note: Radical skeptic about causation and induction; moral sentiments root ethics.

EnlightenmentPhilosophy.name: Enlightenment Philosophy
EnlightenmentPhilosophy.description: Era emphasizing reason, individual rights, and the questioning of traditional authority.

thinkers.name: Voltaire
thinkers.note: Criticized religious dogma; championed freedom of speech and tolerance.

thinkers.name: Jean-Jacques Rousseau
thinkers.note: Explored freedom vs. society in The Social Contract; stressed general will.

thinkers.name: Immanuel Kant
thinkers.note: Unified rationalism & empiricism; argued for the mind’s active role in experience.

NineteenthCenturyPhilosophy.name: 19th-Century Philosophy
NineteenthCenturyPhilosophy.description: Marked by German Idealism, critiques of Enlightenment, socialism, utilitarianism, and existential groundwork.

thinkers.name: Johann Gottlieb Fichte
thinkers.note: Stressed the 'I' as actively positing both self and not-self.

thinkers.name: Friedrich Wilhelm Joseph Schelling
thinkers.note: Nature and spirit as manifestations of the Absolute; creativity key.

thinkers.name: Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel
thinkers.note: Developed dialectical idealism; emphasized Absolute Spirit and historical process.

thinkers.name: Arthur Schopenhauer
thinkers.note: World as Will and Representation; saw existence as driven by blind will.

thinkers.name: Karl Marx
thinkers.note: Class struggle and materialist conception of history; critique of capitalism.

thinkers.name: Friedrich Nietzsche
thinkers.note: 'God is dead'; revaluation of morals; will to power.

thinkers.name: Jeremy Bentham
thinkers.note: Principle of utility; hedonic calculus for maximizing happiness.

thinkers.name: John Stuart Mill
thinkers.note: Refined utilitarian ethics; championed liberty, free speech, women’s rights.

TwentiethCenturyPhilosophy.name: 20th-Century & Contemporary Philosophy
TwentiethCenturyPhilosophy.description: Encompasses analytic philosophy, phenomenology, existentialism, structuralism, postmodernism, and more.

thinkers.name: Bertrand Russell
thinkers.note: Pioneered formal logic, advocated logical analysis of language.

thinkers.name: G.E. Moore
thinkers.note: Common-sense realism, critique of ethical naturalism.

thinkers.name: Ludwig Wittgenstein
thinkers.note: Tractatus vs. Philosophical Investigations; transformation of language philosophy.

thinkers.name: Willard Van Orman Quine
thinkers.note: Critiqued the analytic-synthetic distinction; ontological relativity.

thinkers.name: Edmund Husserl
thinkers.note: Founded phenomenology; studied the structures of consciousness and intentionality.

thinkers.name: Martin Heidegger
thinkers.note: Being and Time; reoriented Western philosophy to question of Being.

thinkers.name: Jean-Paul Sartre
thinkers.note: Existence precedes essence; radical freedom and responsibility.

thinkers.name: Simone de Beauvoir
thinkers.note: The Second Sex; existentialist feminist examining woman as 'Other.'

thinkers.name: Claude Lévi-Strauss
thinkers.note: Applied structuralism to anthropology and myths.

thinkers.name: Michel Foucault
thinkers.note: Analyzed power-knowledge in social institutions; genealogy of discourse.

thinkers.name: Jacques Derrida
thinkers.note: Deconstruction, différance, critique of logocentrism.

thinkers.name: Max Horkheimer
thinkers.note: Co-founder of Frankfurt School; combined Marxism with social research.

thinkers.name: Theodor W. Adorno
thinkers.note: Dialectic of Enlightenment; critique of culture industry.

thinkers.name: Herbert Marcuse
thinkers.note: One-Dimensional Man; critique of capitalist society.

thinkers.name: Jürgen Habermas
thinkers.note: Communicative action and discourse ethics; public sphere theory.

thinkers.name: Charles Sanders Peirce
thinkers.note: Pragmatic maxim; contributions to semiotics.

thinkers.name: William James
thinkers.note: Radical empiricism, the will to believe, religious experience.

thinkers.name: John Dewey
thinkers.note: Applied pragmatism to education, democracy, and experimental inquiry.
